Dear Carlyn E Sperling:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 15, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the following information before
employment may occur:
• (h) Documentation from the department that the person has not been
named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of child abuse or
neglect in Michigan or in any state where the person lived in the 5
years preceding hire.
One of twenty-three new employee files did not have an out-of-state Central
Registry completed as required.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application for renewal of the
license and document the action not less than 60 calendar days before the
expiration date of the license. A renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending recommendation for disciplinary action of
the license.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not provide a renewal application to
foster parents at least 60 days prior to the expiration date of the license.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/24/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/16/2024
2

CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have training in and
maintain a current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation
from the American Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have verification of current CPR/First
Aid certification.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
• (6) An agency must document, in the child's record, within 7 calendar days
after placement, the information specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the
following information:
• (a) All the following child characteristics:
• (iii) Height and weight.
One of six foster care files reviewed and three of eight independent living files
reviewed did not have physical characteristics of youth completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/24/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/16/2024
10/26/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/14/2023
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
• (6) An agency must document, in the child's record, within 7 calendar days
after placement, the information specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the
following information:
• (h) A photograph of the child at the time of placement.
One of six foster care files and two of eight independent living files reviewed did not
have youth picture uploaded within 7 days.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
3

• (c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a greater
frequency is medically indicated:
• (i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within 30
calendar days from the date the child entered into an out-of-
home placement, regardless of the date of the last physical
examination.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not have the initial medical completed
within 30 days of removal as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/24/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/16/2024
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents; the department licensing
authority; the lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as applicable; the
department; and the foster child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency room or inpatient
hospitalization of a foster child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed and one of eight independent living files
reviewed contained situations where youth were taken to hospital emergency room
and an incident report was not provided to required parties.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/24/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/16/2024
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information
before the placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided the information in subsections (a-h) of this rule prior to placement.
4

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and parent
or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least once
every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed and two of eight independent living files
reviewed did not have a service plan completed timely as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

• (3) The record must contain all the following information:
• (d) Placement documentation as required by R 400.12404.

PA 116 722.120 Confidentiality
(3) Notwithstanding subsection (2) and sections 5 and 7(2) of the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.625 and 722.627, information or records in the
possession of the department or the department of licensing and regulatory affairs
may be shared to the extent necessary for the proper functioning of the department
5

or the department of licensing and regulatory affairs in administering child welfare or
child care licensing under this act or in an investigation conducted under section 43b
of the social welfare act, 1939 PA 280, MCL 400.43b. Information or records shared
under this subsection shall not be released by the department or the department of

state or federal law. Neither the department nor the department of licensing and
regulatory affairs shall release or open for inspection any document, report, or
record authored by or obtained from another agency or organization unless 1 of the
conditions of section 7(10) of the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.627,
applies.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency Renewal inspection was completed on 2/16/23 and the CAP was
approved on 2/21/23. The agency was cited for 9 violations, 4 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 4, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 2 of the violation areas and a slight increase in number of
individual incidents in the other 2 areas. In 2023, 12 violations were established, 7
of which were repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the
same number of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to
6

establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was received and reviewed. The agency
noted barriers due to a limited number of medical and dental providers willing to
accept youth insurance. In addition, some providers have been hesitant to provide
the required paperwork which led to a delay in uploading the related paperwork in
a timely manner. The assessment noted the ongoing file reviews that take place
as a result of previous year’s CAP. This occurs as a group once per month and
has resulted in noticeable improvement. The agency also utilizes protected time
for staff to complete data entry, and this has been helpful in working toward
compliance.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. The agency communicates relevant updates in a timely manner. Staff did
not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing. All files were stored securely and there is a
cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency is not contracted with MDHHS to provide foster care placement or
certification services, therefore this is not applicable.
7

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
